subject: Re: [junit] Unit Testing vs Integration Testing

messageBody:
>So said Mike Bresnahan on 2003-06-20 --------------------
>I have experience with integration testing but not much with unit testing.
>I've been reading up on unit testing (e.g. mock objects, test first
>development). However, I have not found an article that explains the
>advantages of unit testing vs integration testing. My perhaps naive hunch
>is that the cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher than that of
>integration testing. It appears this way because a single integration test
>tests a lot more code than a single unit test and takes about the same
>amount of time to construct. Plus it seems to me that a whole suite of
>unit
>tests with 100% code coverage cannot guarantee that even the simplest
>system
>wide behavior is correct (e.g. the web page appears). Am I wrong about
>this? Can someone refer me information about this topic. A scientific
>study paper with real numbers would be welcome.

You have it right. Programmer Tests (your "unit tests") play an entirely different role than Integration Tests. The goal of Programmer Tests is to ensure that object-level behavior is correct (as expected), but may not guarantee correct collaboration among objects. That's why we have Customer Tests and Integration Tests.

Customer Tests allow us to be confident that we're building the right features.

Programmer Tests allow us to be confident that our objects do what we think we asked them to do.

Integration Tests allow us to be confident that our objects play nicely with one another. Integration Tests are often headless (UI-less) Customer Tests.

Programmer Tests run faster than Integration Tests, so we run them more often. That's one of their biggest benefits.

Take care.
